Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Integrated Framework of Political Economy and Government Policy

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Until recently most of the research on public finance and study of the optimal fiscal policy was conducted in idealistic settings where government sets taxes and transfers to maximize a well defined social objective function and commits to follow the optimally chosen policy over time. Although such analysis provides a useful benchmark, it ignores political forces that affect policy making in the real world, such as conflict of interests among political groups, their incentives to change existing policy as they gain or lose political power, and desire to choose policies that favors their constituencies. On the other hand, the political economy literature develops sophisticated models of the behavior of politicians but lags behind the modern developments in macroeconomics and public economics that bring to the forefront incentives of economic agents. An additional limitation of current political economy models is that, in contrast to public and macro- economic work, they often lack the analysis of dynamics of the political process which limits their scope in addressing many important issues in economic policy. The integrated framework that this project develops bridges the gap between the two literatures. In this approach each agent makes economic decisions given current policies while also forming expectations about how those policies might change in future due to changes in political power. At the same time politicians evaluate each policy based on the costs and benefits for their constituencies and how such policies might effect their political standing in the future. The focus of this analysis is both on the development of realistic policy recommendations that can be implemented in the political process, and on understanding how government institutions should be designed to mitigate the political constraints. The primary innovations of this project are, (1) to develop political economy models that make few assumptions about the specific institutional details but focus instead on the key political frictions; (2) to integrate such models with the state of the art models of optimal taxation and social insurance and (3) to expand the scope of the optimal fiscal policy analysis by moving from purely normative exercise to realistic recommendations that take politico-economic process into account. This project is directly relevant for a broad set of issues, including social insurance (health, old-age, and disability) and taxation. It is motivated by the concerns that are frequently raised during policy debates but seldom addressed in academic research. To identify most important policy relevant concerns the project uses not only analytical reasoning but also assembles a dataset on the US state government finance and empirically tests it to identify the most important frictions. The results of the analysis have implications for a wide set of the economic issues such as design of social security, tax code and trade policy.

The CAREER award also funds the establishment of a 'Policy Lab' that will bring together undergraduates, doctoral students, and researchers at MIT and Harvard to address fiscal policy questions using economic analysis. A new doctoral level course with an accompanying new textbook will allow other institutions to incorporate this new approach to public finance into their own graduate training programs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The CAREER grant allowed me to undertake a large number of research projects. With the support of this grant I was able to publish fourteen articles in peer-reviewed journals, complete and submit five more articles to peer-reviewed journals, collect several dataset and create software to study numerous issues related to the effect of government policies on the economy and their interaction with political institutions. Much of the work broadly falls in several categories.

In a series of papers, I developed new theoretical and computations tools for understanding the effect of government policies on economic outcomes and welfare. This work described trade-offs that one needs to consider in designing taxes and social insurance programs in settings with realistic degree of heterogeneity and idiosyncratic uncertainty. The computational software that accompanies this work allows one to calculate informationally constrained-optimum in the state-of-the-art lifecycle models that match a broad set of empirical facts about behavior of individuals. This software also computes welfare gains relative to existing tax code. In addition, my work sheds light on other aspect of government policy such as fossil fuel taxation and government debt management. In both cases I provide novel formulas that characterize optimal carbon taxes and debt level as function of key economic parameters.

Another strand of my work studies the interaction of political frictions and economic policies. Several of my papers re-examine the implications of the standard normative theories in public finance in the settings in which the policymaker faces additional constraints, such as inability to fully commit to her future actions. Since some of the workhorse theoretical tools are not applicable in such settings, in one of my papers I develop an entirely new toolbox to study such problems. Moreover, we show that standard models augmented with political frictions can naturally explain such empirical patterns such as emergence of populist cycles in countries with weak political institutions or conflict over natural resources.

I also developed novel techniques to study the channels through which non-market political institutions, such as communist governments of Russia and China in 20th century, affect the economy. In addition, I compiled novel datasets for these two countries and applies my techniques. The analysis of these datasets revealed new insights about the structural change and economic growth that those countries experiences.

My grant also facilitated my effort to disseminate findings of my research to a broader audience. I wrote several review articles explaining my work in a manner accessible to the general interest economic audience and graduate students. These articles should facilitate learning of the new techniques and widen their application.

I also developed several new PhD courses while working at MIT, Yale and Princeton and advised over ten PhD students. Many of these students were supported in part by my grant. These students provided valuable assistance in my research and obtained in-depth training in modern theories of policymaking in realistic institutional settings.

With the support of the grant I was able to create Political Economy Public Finance workshop that runs annually as a part of the NBER Summer Institute. This workshop brings together specialists in public finance, political economy and macroeconomics to discuss the interaction of political frictions and government policies. The workshop attracted a large number of researches and graduate students from both U.S.  and abroad.
